questions.text: A 25-year-old man feels embarrassed to talk with his peers because of the persistence of a high-pitched childhood voice. At times, he has noticed that on pressing the thyroid prominence, he was able to produce an adult-type voice. Which of the following thyroplasty procedure would benefit this patient?

choices.text: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
Lengthening or tightening of vocal cord

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of puberphonia, also known as mutational falsetto voice. A type III thyroplasty causing shortening or relaxation of the vocal cord would benefit this patient.

When larynx matures at puberty, the voice becomes low-pitched in males. Puberphonia (mutational falsetto voice) is a condition in which the transition from high-pitched childhood voice to adult male voice fails to occur. The vocal cords are stretched and pose high tension.

Pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and a low tone voice can be produced. This is called Gutzmann’s pressure test.

In type III thyroplasty, the vocal cord is shortened and hence the tension is reduced. This can revert from a childhood voice to an adult one.

Type of thyroplasty Procedure done
Type I Medial displacement of vocal cord
Type II Lateral displacement of vocal cord
Type III Shortening (relaxation) of vocal cord
Type IV Lengthening (tightening) of vocal cord

  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

It occurs due to edema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords in the glottis.

Key clinical features

  • History of smoking and/or voice abuse.
  • Hoarseness is the most common symptom.
  • Patients use false cords for voice production and this gives them a low-pitched and rough voice.

On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swellings. They appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

Treatment

  • Voice rest and cessation of smoking
  • Decortication of the vocal cords, i.e. removal of a strip of epithelium
  • Speech therapy for proper voice production.

Other options

Option B: Laryngeal papilloma/ squamous papilloma are benign tumors of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They occur in children (juvenile papillomatosis) as well as adults. Patients present with hoarseness, dyspnea or stridor.

Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. 

The image below shows laryngeal papilloma. 

Option C: A Vocal polyp is caused by vocal abuse or misuses such as sudden shouting resulting in hemorrhage and submucosal edema. It presents with hoarseness and diplophonia. In case of a large polyp, dyspnea, stridor or choking may occur.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as soft, smooth, mobile, and pedunculated mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly unilateral.

Treatment is by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows a vocal polyp.

Option D: Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are also caused by vocal abuse or misuse. It most commonly affects teachers, actors, singers, vendors, and talkative school children. Patients complain of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and neck pain during prolonged talking.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as a greyish or white pin-head-sized mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly symmetrical (bilateral).

Small vocal nodules are treated conservatively with speech therapy. Large ones are treated by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease, acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Betahistine (vertin), used in the medical management of Meniere's disease acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels, thereby improving the microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea. It is also found to inhibit the vestibular nuclei activity.

Other drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease are

  • Prochlorperazine (stemetil), is a vestibular sedative.
  • Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control recurrent attacks.
  • Propantheline bromide (probanthine), an anticholinergic agent is also found to be effective.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves does not supply the external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
The external auditory canal is not supplied by the IX cranial nerve/ Glossopharyngeal nerve.

Nerve supply of External Auditory Canal (EAC):

  • Anterior wall and roof are supplied by: auriculotemporal branch (V3) of V cranial nerve.
  • The posterior wall and floor are supplied by: auricular branch of the vagus nerve (X cranial nerve).
  • The posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibers of cranial nerve VII through the auricular branch of the vagus nerve.

Applied significance:

  • In herpes zoster oticus, lesions are seen in the distribution of the facial nerve. That is why the concha, posterior part of the tympanic membrane, and postauricular region are also involved. 
  • In the case of acoustic neuroma, the facial nerve is affected. That is why there is hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall (Hitzelberger’s sign) in acoustic neuroma. 

The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm.

It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts:

  • Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm
  • Inner bony part- 16mm

questions.text: Name the surgery for which the following set of instruments is used.
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments is used in tonsillectomy.

Instrument 1: Boyle-Davis mouth gag is used for opening the mouth and depressing tongue for doing surgery. Various sized tongue blades are used along with it according to the age of the patient.

Uses of Boyle Davis mouth gag are:

  • Pharyngoplasty
  • Tonsillectomy 
  • Surgery of soft palate
  • Adenoidectomy
  • Excision of angiofibroma

Instrument 2: Draffin’s bipod

Each pod has four rings. They can be assembled to vary the height at which the tongue blade of the Boyle-Davis mouth gag can be suspended. The lower end of each pod can be placed in one of the several depressions in Magauran’s plate (vide infra).

Instrument 3: Denis Browne’s tonsil holding forceps is used for holding the tonsil during tonsillectomy by dissection method.

Instrument 4: Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor:

One end is used to dissect the tonsil and the other end to retract the anterior pillar to inspect the tonsillar fossa for any bleeding point.

Instrument 5: Eves’ tonsil snare is used for tonsillectomy. After the tonsil has been dissected till its lower pole, snare is passed round the tonsil to engage the pedicle and then firmly closed. It crushes and cuts the pedicle thereby minimizing bleeding. Wire used in snare is number 25 SWG.

Instrument 6: Waugh’s tonsil dissection forceps is used for incision in mucous membrane and dissection of the tonsil.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female patient presents to your clinic with nasal obstruction. Physical examination revealed a wide, roomy nasal cavity, a pale nasal mucosa and greyish-black dry crusts that improved after modified Young's procedure. Identify the clinical feature likely to be associated with this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis, and merciful anosmia is associated with this condition. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. The patient presents with nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers. It is associated with foul odor from their nose but the patient is unable to smell it because of merciful anosmia. Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements. On examination nasal mucosa appears pale, greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. 

Medical management is done using warm saline for nasal irrigation, removal of crusts and administering local antibiotics like kemicetine antiozaena solution(containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2).

Surgical management involves:

  • In Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months and during this time, the mucosa comes back to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young operation is a modified version of Young's operation where the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same compared to Young's operation and it is done to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. 

Other options:

Option A: Offensive cheesy discharge is seen in an uncommon condition called rhinitis caseosa. It is usually unilateral and affects males. The disease arises from chronic sinusitis with the collection of inspissated cheesy material.

Option C: Paroxysmal sneezing refers to bouts of sneezing in the morning and is associated with allergic rhinitis and vasomotor rhinitis. 

Option D: Allergic salute is the constant upward rubbing motion of the nose simulating a salute, leading to transverse nasal crease across the dorsum of the nose. Seen in allergic rhinitis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. An audible bruit is heard over mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinne test was negative.  A tumor of the middle ear is suspected. All of the following signs can be seen by otoscopy except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a woman with progressive conductive hearing loss, tinnitus and audible bruit heard over the mastoid suggests a diagnosis of a ‘glomus tumor’. The Phelp sign on CECT scan (not otoscopy) is the erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest, seen in glomus jugulare tumors. It is intact in glomus tympanicum.

The cell of origin in the glomus tumor is paraganglionic cells (not perivascular cells). These cells are derived from the neural crest. They are paragangliomas of the glomus bodies found in the mastoid.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear.

It is of 2 types:

  • Glomus jugulare: It arises from the dome of the jugular bulb causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.
  • Glomus tympanicum: It arises from the promontory of the middle ear and causes aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

The rule of 10 is seen in the glomus tumor. It comprises of

  • 10% familial
  • 10% multicentric
  • 10% functional

It is 5 times more common in women. Common presenting features include:

  • Progressive conductive hearing loss
  • Tinnitus in glomus tumors is pulsatile, of swishing character, synchronous with a pulse, and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Audible bruit heard over the mastoid with a stethoscope in all stages

Investigations would include:

  • Phelp's sign-on CECT scan helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumor by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter.
  • MRI gives the soft tissue extent of the tumor.
  • Four vessel angiography is necessary when the CT head shows the involvement of a jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension.
  • A biopsy is never done since it’s a highly vascular tumor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of the nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. The histology of the biopsied specimen is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Both streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given together for a minimum period of 4–6 weeks
Steroids can be combined with antibiotics so as to reduce fibrosis.
Surgical intervention may be required to establish the airway and correct nasal deformity.
Treatment can be stopped after a culture from biopsy material turns negative

questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative.

It can be diagnosed as rhinoscleroma, as the patient had a history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodule, which corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma 

Adding to this, the given histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose.

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. 

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with antibiotics so as to reduce fibrosis.. Surgical intervention may be necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman came with complaints of progressive hearing loss and tinnitus for a few weeks.  Pure tone audiometry was done as shown below. Which of the following phenomenon is seen in the above patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pregnant women presenting with progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and pure tone audiometry showing Carhart's notch is suggestive of Otosclerosis. Paracusis willisii is seen in patients with stapedial otosclerosis.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. The louder voice is better transmitted through the fixed stapes. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis willisii.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy and menopause.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis  asymptomatic

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne.

Tympanometry shows an ossicular stiffness type of curve. Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz known as Carhart's notch as shown below.

 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

The types of stapedial otosclerosis are:

  • Anterior focus
  • Posterior focus
  • Circumferential
  • Biscuit type (thick plate)
  • Obliterative

 

Option B - Tullio phenomenon is seen in Meniere's disease. In this phenomenon, loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This is due to the distended saccule lying against the footplate of the stapes.

Option C - Recruitment is seen in diseases of the cochlea such as Meniere's disease and presbycusis, in which there is reduced tolerance to loudness. 

Option D - Roll-over phenomenon is seen in patients with acoustic neuroma. It is the reduction of discrimination score when the loudness is increased beyond a particular level. This reduction is disproportionate to the pure tone hearing loss

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:

  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with nasal obstruction. She states that her friends make fun of her because she emits a bad odor. Physical examination reveals wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts and a pale nasal mucosa. Which of the following is not a component of the Kemicetine solution used in the management of this disease?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is not a component of the Kemicetine solution commonly used in the management of this disease.

The clinical scenario with nasal obstruction, bad odor, wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. The Kemicetine solution used in the management of atrophic rhinitis contains chloramphenicol, oestradiol, and vitamin D2.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic nasal inflammation associated with atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis includes:

  • Hereditary
  • More commonly in females than males
  • White and yellow races are more susceptible
  • Nutritional deficiency- Deficiency of vitamin A, D, or iron
  • Infective- Causative agents include Klebsiella ozaena, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Autoimmune process

The clinical presentation of atrophic rhinitis includes nasal obstruction, foul smell from the nose with merciful anosmia, crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, wide nasal turbinates, and epistaxis.

Treatment

  • Nasal irrigation and crust removal using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium bi-borate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine anti-ozaena solution contains chloramphenicol, estradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.
  • Surgical management includes the modified Young's operation or narrowing the nasal turbinates.

  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

questions.text: An ENT resident performs the following procedure under general anesthesia to wash out the pus in a patient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. This patient is usually placed in which of the following positions while performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above image is proof puncture (antral lavage). While performing this procedure under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position 

Proof puncture (antral lavage): This procedure involves puncturing the medial wall of the maxillary sinus in the region of the inferior meatus and irrigating the sinus.

Indications:

  • Chronic and subacute maxillary sinusitis with dual purpose of confirming the diagnosis and washing out the pus.
  • To collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

Contraindications:

  • Acute maxillary sinusitis for fear of osteomyelitis.

Note: Sitting position is preferred in all adults when using local anesthesia. But under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position 

Rose position is a surgical position that involves head and neck extension with a sandbag near the shoulder blade as shown in the below image.


Other options:

Barking-dog position is a surgical position in which the neck is flexed on the thorax and the head is extended on atlanto-occipital joint. This position is used during laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and oesophagoscopy.


Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with the head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.


Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions and for patients with a nasogastric tube.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a history of discharge from the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo syndrome. 

Patients with petrositis may present with Gradenigo syndrome. Gradenigo syndrome is a triad with the following symptoms:

  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve VI  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve V involvement
  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger sign is edema over the mastoid, which is secondary to the thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint dislocation. Patient presents with neck pain and torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their corresponding tympanometry curves.
  1. Otosclerosis
  2. Retracted tympanic membrane
  3. CSOM
  4. Ossicular discontinuity
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  1. Otosclerosis - Type As curve
  2. Retracted tympanic membrane - Type C curve
  3. CSOM - Type B curve
  4. Ossicular discontinuity - Type Ad curve

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube.

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more of sound energy than a compliant one.

By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.

Tympanometry is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

questions.text: A nasogastric tube could not be passed in a newborn having cyclical hypoxia. There is an absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge and there was no misting on a metal spatula under the nose. Which of the following is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, and McGovern’s technique is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition.

Choanal atresia is characterised by a persistent bucco-nasal membrane, leaving a sheet of tissue at the back of the nose and separating it from the pharynx.

Features of choanal atresia include: 

  • Cyclical hypoxia: This is observed in the newborn, where the baby cries, taking in air through the mouth. This relieves the hypoxia, but upon settling down for a while and closing its mouth, the baby struggles to breathe and becomes hypoxic again.
  • Presence of mucoid nasal discharge
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Absence of misting on a cold metal spatula held under the nose

Choanal atresia can be confirmed by putting methylene blue dye into the nose and observing its passage to the pharynx or putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph. The most useful investigation though is an axial CT scan.

Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at 1.5 years of age.

McGovern's technique involves the use of a feeding nipple with a large hole, which provides a good oral airway in the infant, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Trotter’s method is used to control epistaxis. The patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood, and breathe quietly from the mouth, as shown in the image below.

 

Option C: Epley’s manoeuvre is used in the treatment of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo, as shown in the image below.

 

Option D: Pringle maneuver is used to minimize blood loss during hepatic surgery by clamping the vascular pedicle (free margin of lesser omentum), as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was subjected to a tuning fork test. A vibrating tuning fork was placed on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stopped hearing, it was brought beside his external meatus. The patient could still hear the ringing sound. Repeating the same test in the opposite ear yielded the same result. On placing a vibrating tuning fork on his forehead, it was lateralized to the right ear. What is the likely inference?

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
The given scenario shows a positive Rinne test, indicating air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Since Weber’s test is lateralized to the right ear and Rinne’s test is normal, there is sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear.

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus(EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • It is considered positive (normal) when the AC>BC. This is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC. This is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

In the Weber test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead, or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. Normally, it is heard equally in both ears. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you least prefer to perform an endoscopic sinus surgery?

choices.text: A 49-year-old diabetic male suffering from Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball
A 44-year-old Chronic bacterial sinusitis that is unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
A 33-year-old with frontal osteomyelitis with Potts puffy tumor
A 38-year-old with mucocele of sphenoid sinus

questions.solution:
Among the given options, endoscopic sinus surgery would be least preferable in a 33-year-old with frontal osteomyelitis with Potts puffy tumor. Osteomyelitis is considered a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery. The rest of the options indicate patients who would be considered candidates for endoscopic sinus surgery.

The following are considered indications for endoscopic sinus surgery.

  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Antrochoanal polyp
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis/ diffuse nasal polyposis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball or nasal polypi.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus.

The Contraindications include:

  • Disease inaccessible by endoscopic procedures, Ex:- lateral frontal sinus disease and stenosis of the internal opening of frontal sinus.
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Threatened intracranial or intraorbital complication

questions.text: Two patients have been posted for a tracheostomy procedure. The operating surgeon performs tracheostomy through the level of 2nd - 3rd tracheal rings in the first patient and  4th - 5th tracheal ring in the second patient. What is the type of tracheostomy procedure conducted in these patients respectively?

choices.text: Low tracheostomy is done in both patients

questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Mid tracheostomy and Low tracheostomy is performed by the surgeon in first and second patient respectively.

Mid tracheostomy is done through the 2nd and 3rd ring and Low tracheostomy is done below the level of isthmus i.e through the 4th and 5th tracheal ring.

High tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (Isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal ring). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: A 40-year-old baker presented with crust formation in his nose, mostly confined to the anterior part of the nasal septum. When he tried to remove those crusts, it caused ulceration and epistaxis. A diagnosis of rhinitis sicca is made. The pathophysiology in this case is ___________________

choices.text: Squamous metaplasia of Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland atrophy
Squamous metaplasia of Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland hypertrophy
Squamous metaplasia of Non-Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland hypertrophy
Squamous metaplasia of Non-Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland atrophy

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of Rhinitis sicca, the pathophysiology is squamous metaplasia of Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland atrophy.

Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. It is confined to the anterior third of nose particularly of the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. Treatment consists of correction of the occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment or one with an antibiotic and steroid to the affected part.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with weakness in the right side of the face for 24 hours. Thorough investigations were done which did not reveal any significant abnormality. The doctor as a diagnosis of exclusion prescribed him prednisolone for 5 days and 3 weeks later, he had recovered. Which of the following findings can be seen in his condition?

choices.text: The side of the face affected is the same side as the affected nerve
Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the contralateral side
Corner of the mouth is drawn to affected side
If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn down and inwards

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of acute onset facial paralysis recovering within 3 weeks is a classical case of Bell's palsy and the side of the face affected is the same side as the affected nerve is a finding that can be seen in this condition. 

Bell's palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Bell's palsy is idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. The onset of Bell's palsy is fairly abrupt. 

If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn up and out - this is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Decreased tearing, hyperacusis, taste disturbances, otalgia, weakness of the facial muscles, poor eyelid closure, etc can be seen. When the patient smiles, the face becomes distorted and lateralizes to the side opposite the palsy. Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side affected by palsy. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. The use of paper tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep prevents corneal drying. For patients with permanent paralysis cosmetic surgical procedures have been used to restore a relatively symmetric appearance to the face.

Approximately 80% of patients recover within a few weeks or months. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favourable prognostic sign. Recurrences are seen in some cases (7%). Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigation.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital complaining of reduced hearing in the right ear. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. All of the following are uses of this instrument except?

choices.text: To determine the degree of hearing loss

questions.solution:
The image is of a digital audiometer (pure tone audiometer). A digital audiometer is a lightweight device that is portable and can be used to perform hearing tests, including pure tone audiometry. This device does not measure acoustic reflexes. 

Acoustic reflex is measured using the impedance audiometer.

An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram.

The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.

Uses of pure tone audiometer:

  • To measure the threshold of hearing of air and bone conduction
  • Helps to predict speech reception threshold (SRT)
  • To diagnose the type and degree of hearing loss.
  • For the prescription of hearing aids
  • Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes
  • A record can be kept for future reference.

Impedance audiometry includes tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurement, which are objective tests of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing).

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. CT scan of paranasal sinuses shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most probable diagnosis based on the above findings.

It is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. It presents with sinonasal polyposis and mucin which consists of eosinophils, Charcot Leyden crystal, and fungal hyphae. 

CT scan shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. There is an expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure but no fungal invasion.

Treatment: Endoscopic surgical drainage and ventilation along with systemic steroids.

Other options:

Option B: Ethmoidal polyps are multiple and bilateral and arise from the lateral wall of the nose. Patients are mostly adults and present with bilateral nasal obstruction, anosmia/ hyposmia, sneezing, rhinorrhea, and a polypoidal mass from the nostril.

Option C: Antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. They are usually unilateral and are seen in children and young adults. They present with unilateral nasal obstruction. X-rays of the paranasal sinuses show opacity of the maxillary sinus,

Option D: Nasoethmoidal carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, diplopia, lateral displacement of the eyeball, broadening of nasal root, and retro-orbital pain.

questions.text: During a measles epidemic, a 5-year-old boy, Rohan is posted for a tonsillectomy procedure. On the day of surgery, he is found to have an acute infection in the upper respiratory tract. His Hb level is 10.5 g%. Which of the given history/findings is a contraindication for the operation?
questions.solution:
Tonsillectomy is contraindicated in the presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, as bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis, as bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: The ENT resident uses the following system to classify the maxillary carcinoma. The 2 horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the below image are known as _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows Lederman’s classification and the two horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the above image are called as Sebileau lines, one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through the floors of antrum.

 Sebileau lines divides the area into:

  • Suprastructure: It contains ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses and the olfactory area of the nose.
  • Mesostructure: It has a maxillary sinus and the respiratory part of the nose.
  • Infrastructure: It contains the alveolar process.

This classification further uses vertical lines, extending down the medial walls of orbit to separate ethmoidal sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses.

Other options:

  • Ohngren’s line is an imaginary line passing through medial canthus of eye and angle of mandible
  • Lefort's lines are used for the classification of maxillary fractures

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with enlargement of neck nodes. Examination of the left ear reveals conductive hearing loss with the tympanogram showing the following type of curve. Involvement of which of the following cranial nerves completes the features of trotter's triad seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with type B typanogram is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Conductive deafness (i.e. eustachian tube blockage) along with the involvement of 5th and 10th cranial nerve together constitutes Trotter's triad seen in this condition.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can cause,

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube blockage),
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of CN V and
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of CN X

This is collectively called as Trotter’s triad.

Commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. It is mostly seen in fifth to seventh decades with Males being more prone than females.

Presenting symptoms include,

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common)
  • Hearing loss
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Cranial nerve palsies - 6th Cranial nerve is most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves.
  • Headache
  • Earache
  • Neck pain
  • Weight loss

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female patient presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive hearing loss at higher tones. She also classically complains of difficulty in understanding speech and inability to feel her contact lenses. Audiometric tests were done as follows. What is the diagnosis?

Recruitment - absent
Rollover phenomenon - present
Short increment sensitivity index (SISI) - 16%
Stapedial reflex - absent
Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) - Interaural latency of wave V is >0.2ms
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the interpretation of audiometric tests, is suggestive of the diagnosis as Vestibular schwannoma.

Vestibular schwannoma is a benign tumour arising from the vestibular nerve due to the abnormal proliferation of Schwann cells. Bilateral vestibular schwannoma is seen in neurofibromatosis type 2. It is common in both sexes between 40-60 years of age. It usually presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive retro-cochlear sensorineural hearing loss at higher tones with poor speech discrimination. 

Tumour growth presents with corneal and facial hypesthesia (inability to feel the contact lens in the given case) due to the involvement of the trigeminal nerve. Involvement of the facial nerve presents as hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall, known as the Hitzelbergers sign and defective taste and lacrimation. Involvement of lower cranial nerves presents as dysphagia, aspiration, voice change, and regurgitation. Rarely cerebellar symptoms may also be seen.

  • Pure tone audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in high frequencies.
  • Speech audiometry shows the roll-over phenomenon.
  • The absence of the recruitment phenomenon is noted.
  • Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) ranges from 0-20%.
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) demonstrates a significant delay of >0.2 ms in wave V between the two ears.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with gadolinium contrast is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

Surgical removal by X-knife, Gamma knife, or Cyberknife is the treatment of choice. Radiotherapy has no role. 

Other options:

Option A - Presbycusis is the physiological hearing loss due to old age and usually manifests at 65 years of age. Presbycusis occurs due to sensory, neural, metabolic, and conductive pathologies and presents predominantly cochlear hearing loss patterns. High-frequency hearing loss with tinnitus are the presenting complaints with positive recruitment phenomenon. Additional features of corneal hypesthesia are absent. 

Option B - Meniere's disease, also known as endolymphatic hydrops, occurs due to overdistension of the inner ear with endolymph. It is more common in males than females. It may be unilateral or bilateral. Cardinal features are:

  • Episodic vertigo
  • Fluctuating hearing loss of cochlear type
  • Tinnitus  
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.

Option C - Noise-induced hearing loss(NIHL) is a preventable cause of hearing loss and is an occupational hazard. NIHL causes damage to outer hair cells more than the inner hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. There is symmetrical hearing loss and shows a cochlear pattern on audiometric tests. The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz, both for air and bone conduction. Speech frequencies are also affected.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

questions.text: During your ENT viva, the examiner shows the following image and asks you to name all the paranasal sinuses which open into the space present behind the structure marked as "?". You would answer all the following paranasal sinuses except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "?" in the above image is the middle turbinate and the space present behind it is known as the middle meatus. All the above paranasal sinus opens into the middle meatus except the Posterior ethmoidal sinus, which opens into the superior meatus.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: It includes,

  • Maxillary sinus(Antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal.

All of the above sinuses open into the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to basal lamella of middle turbinate.

Posterior group: It includes,

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is performing mastoid surgery on a patient through an endaural approach. The surgeon would cut through which of the following parts of pinna for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The area between the tragus and crux of the helix is called the incisura terminalis (marked 2). The mastoid is endaurally approached through this structure as it is devoid of cartilage. 

The parts of the pinna are depicted in the image below. 

 

The ear can be surgically approached in three ways - endomeatal, endaural, and postaural approaches.

The mastoid is endaurally approached through Lempert's incision. 

Lempert I - It is a semicircular incision made from the 12 o'clock to 6 o'clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony-cartilaginous junction.

Lempert II - Starts from the first incision at 12 o'clock and passes through the incisura terminalis and does not cut the cartilage. 

It is used for :

  • Excision of osteomas or exostosis of the ear canal
  • Large tympanic membrane perforations
  • Attic cholesteatomas
  • Modified radical mastoidectomy

 

In endomeatal or transcanal approach Rosen’s incision is used. It is used for stapedectomy, exploratory tympanotomy to find the cause of conductive hearing loss, inlay myringoplasty, and ossicular reconstruction.

It consists of two parts:

  • A small vertical incision at 12 o’clock position near the annulus.
  • A curvilinear incision starting at 6 o’clock position to meet the first incision in the posterosuperior region of the canals, 5–7 mm away from the annulus.

 

Wilde’s incision is used in postaural approach.

  • It starts at the highest attachment of the pinna and follows the curve of retroauricular groove, lying 1 cm behind it. The incision ends at the mastoid tip.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Samter's triad?
questions.solution:
Allergic rhinitis is not a component of the Samter's triad.

Samter’s triad is associated with aetiology of the ethmoidal polyp. It consists of

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

Other etiological factors of ethmoidal polyp:

  • Chronic rhinosinusitis especially NARES (non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome).
    Asthma
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic fungal sinusitis
  • Kartagener syndrome- This consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus and ciliary dyskinesia.
  • Young syndrome- It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.
  • Churg–Strauss syndrome- Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma.
  • Nasal mastocytosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing for 2 months. He mentions that he is taking hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He works at a cement manufacturing factory. Otoscopy findings are normal. Rinne’s test result is positive in both ears. Audiometry results are shown below. What is the likely cause of his hearing loss?
questions.solution:
The pure-tone audiogram shown in the given image shows an acoustic dip at 4000 Hz, which is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss. 

The patient's employment history (working at a cement factory) suggests constant exposure to loud noise. Positive Rinne's test result in both ears suggests that air conduction is better than bone conduction, i.e. absence of conductive hearing loss or presence of sensorineural hearing loss.

Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120–155 dB, such as explosions and gunshots, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the organ of Corti. 

The patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in a noisy environment. This condition is irreversible and is managed with hearing aids. 

Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

Other options:

Option A: Medication adverse effects (ototoxicity) cause bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics, loop diuretics (not thiazides), antimalarials, cisplatin, and NSAIDs like ibuprofen, salicylates, and indomethacin.

Option B: Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Pure-tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz, which is known as Carhart's notch. There is a loss of air conduction in the lower frequencies.

The audiogram given below shows Carhart's notch, which is seen in otosclerosis.

Option D: Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph.

World Hearing Day is celebrated on March 3, 2022. Globally, over one billion people are at risk of hearing loss due to loud volumes for long periods. Hearing loss caused by loud sounds is permanent; however, it is also completely preventable. The theme for this year's campaign is "To hear for life, listen with care"

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: A patient complaining of vertigo without hearing loss has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon performs a diagnostic maneuver and cautiously performs a therapeutic maneuver. What is the diagnostic maneuver?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo without hearing loss is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is characterized by vertigo, recurrent brief (<1 minute) episodes triggered by specific head movements, and is not associated with hearing loss or other neurological symptoms.

It is thought to be caused by the dislodgement of crystals of calcium carbonate from the degenerating macula of the utricle. When this crystal settles on the cupula of the posterior canal, it causes displacement of the cupula and vertigo. 

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, cerebellum, temporal lobe, or multiple sclerosis) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps to differentiate a peripheral from a central lesion.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver: The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested. Then the examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus. 

The features of nystagmus differentiate between BPPV and central lesions: 

Nystagmus BPPV Central lesions
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration <1 minute >1 minute
Direction fixed, towards the lower-placed ear changing
The result on repetitions of the test nystagmus is not seen (fatiguable) nystagmus persists (nonfatiguable)
Symptoms during the test severe vertigo Absent/mild

The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which displaces the otolith out of the posterior canal. This ends the sensation of vertigo with positional changes relieving the symptoms.

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of a sudden loss of taste and hearing loss. He also says he is unable to close one eye and tears do not stop flowing. On examination, there are lesions In the ear as shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of loss of taste, sudden hearing loss, inability to close one eye, and epiphora along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus).

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy.

Clinically, the patients present with all symptoms of facial palsy along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna. The involvement of chorda tympani results in a loss of taste. 

The illustration given below shows the clinical features seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

It may also be associated with hearing loss and vertigo due to the involvement of the 8th cranial nerve. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve.

The treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome involves antiviral medications like acyclovir or famciclovir, as well as corticosteroids like prednisone.

Other options:

Option A: Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Bell's palsy.

 

Option C: Moebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/ bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing abnormal ocular abduction.

Option D: Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of:

  1. Facial paralysis
  2. Swelling of lips
  3. Fissured tongue

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with poor dental hygiene presents to you with complaints of severe pain during swallowing, and difficulty in opening the mouth. He also has a neck swelling, as shown in the image, which he says has been increasing over the past 3 days. O/E there is a woody hard swelling of the floor of the mouth. This condition can occur due to infection in all of the following compartments except _________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ludwig's angina, which occurs due to infection in the Sublingual, Submaxillary, and Submental compartment of Submandibular space (Here Parotid space is not involved).

Ludwig’s Angina is the infection of submandibular space. 

Submandibular space lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of mouth and the tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other side. It is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle:

  • Sublingual compartment (above the mylohyoid).
  • Submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid).

Both compartments freely communicate in the midline with the opposite side. Therefore infection rapidly becomes bilateral.

Dental infections are the most common cause and account for 80% of the cases.

Clinical features:

  • Marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus.
  • When infection is localized to the sublingual space, structures in the floor of the mouth are swollen and tongue seems to be pushed up and back.
  • When the infection spreads to submaxillary space, submental and submandibular regions become swollen, tender and impart woody-hard feel.
  • Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess.
  • The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward threatening the airway.

Treatment:

  • Systemic antibiotics.
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess.
  • Tracheostomy, if there is severe obstruction of airway.

questions.text: The most appropriate option for hearing rehabilitation in Michel aplasia would be
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male had a history of left ear discharge for the past 4 weeks and has not completed the treatment course for the same. He now has a fever with rigors.  Clinical examination shows a swollen mastoid. A CECT of the head shows the delta sign. Which of the following should not be offered as a treatment option in this case?
questions.solution:
Ligation of the internal jugular vein can be used as a treatment option for the given clinical scenario (and not ligation of the external jugular vein, which is given in option) of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is indicated only when antibiotic and surgical treatment have failed to control embolic phenomenon and rigors, or tenderness and swelling along the jugular vein.

Delta sign on CECT in a patient with ear discharge for 4 weeks, incomplete treatment, and presenting with fever and chills along with a swollen mastoid is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It occurs as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis, masked mastoiditis or chronic suppuration of middle ear and cholesteatoma.

It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.

Clinical features:

  • Hectic Picket- Fence type of fever with rigours. 
  • Headache
  • Griesinger’s sign- This is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Oedema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid.
  • Papilloedema
  • Tenderness along the jugular vein (seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein). 

Investigations:

  • Blood culture to find out causative organisms.
  • CSF analysis is normal except increased CSF pressure and helps rule out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows:
    • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis.
    • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma.
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign.

Treatment:

  • Intravenous antibacterial therapy
  • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus
  • Ligation of the internal jugular vein
  • Anticoagulant therapy

below and above the Ohngren’s line. Which of the following option is true regarding the prognosis of maxillary tumour?

questions.text: During a radiographical imaging procedure, a person is positioned in such a way that the X-ray beam comes from a 30-degree cephalocaudal angle as shown in the image given below. The X-ray view shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The X-ray view shown in the image is Schuller’s view.

Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of the skull. The central beam of X-rays passes from one side of the head and is at an angle of 30° to the radiographic plate. The key area seen in this view is the antrum and upper part of the attic. This angulation prevents overlap of images of two mastoid bones. The radiograph for each mastoid is taken separately.

Other options:

Option A: Law’s view: the patient lies in such a way that the sagittal plane of the skull is parallel to the film and the X-ray beam is projected 15° cephalocaudal, a lateral mastoid air cells view without overlap of the opposite side. The below image shows Law’s view.

Option C: Towne’s view: angled anteroposterior view used to demonstrate the occipital bone, foramen magnum, dorsum sellae, and petrous ridges.

Option D: Caldwell's view (or occipitofrontal view) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 20° to orbitomeatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the opd with the complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  Which of the following is true with respect to the stridor seen in this baby?

choices.text: Increases in prone position and subsides on crying
Subsides on prone position and increases with crying
Subsides both on crying and prone position
Increases with both prone position and crying

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of laryngomalacia, as the image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis and the stridor associated with this condition subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying.

Excessively flaccid supraglottic larynx, getting sucked in during inspiration, resulting in stridor is the typical feature of laryngomalacia. It is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. 

Direct laryngoscopy shows elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds, and prominent arytenoids. 

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.  It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised individuals.

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis.

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus. 

The local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge is typically seen in invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

A definitive diagnosis is done with a biopsy and histopathologic examination. It is the most sensitive and specific method. It reveals aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles. 

Among the imaging techniques used for diagnosis, MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice. 1,3 beta D- glucan assay, which is helpful for the identification of most fungi, cannot be used for the diagnosis of mucormycosis.

Management is by amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues. The underlying cause and risk factors should also be addressed.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It presents as nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A young woman presented to the emergency with epistaxis due to multiple episodes of continuous violent sneezes. To control the bleeding the following technique was performed as shown in the image given below. This method helps her to control bleeding from the septal branches of all of the following arteries, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows Trotter’s method. This method helps her to control bleeding from all of the given arteries, except the septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery. 

Trotter's method is a step to control epistaxis from Little’s area. Here, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth and pinching the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes. The septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery does not take part in the vascular anastomoses seen in this area. Hence, it fails to prevent bleeding from this artery.

Little’s area is situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. Septal branches of four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus. The arteries include:

  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery
  • Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery

Note: Woodruff's plexus is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults. It is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to your clinic with complaints of fatigue, weight loss and difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. A barium swallow is performed which shows the following finding. What is the most common site of carcinoma in such patients?
questions.solution:
The post-cricoid region is a common site for carcinoma in females suffering from this condition.

The barium swallow shows an esophagal web, which refers to an esophagal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen, as shown in the image below. Esophageal web is associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome. 

The post-cricoid region is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina. It is a common site for carcinoma in females suffering from Plummer–Vinson syndrome.

Patients are usually asymptomatic, however, if the stenosis is severe, symptoms include dysphagia and regurgitation of food. 

Triad seen in Plummer-Vinson Syndrome/ Patterson-Kelly-Brown Syndrome:

  • Iron Deficiency Anemia
  • Esophageal webs
  • Dysphagia

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl complains that she has a feeling of obstruction in the nose while breathing. She has a history of frequent colds on exposure to dust. On examination, Cottle’s test is negative, and the given finding is seen. The mass does not disappear on blowing the nose. On probe testing, the mass feels soft, can be moved up and down, and does not bleed easily on probing. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of nasal obstruction in a young person with a history of allergic rhinitis along with the image showing a pink fleshy unilateral swelling in the nasal cavity is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp.

Antrochoanal polyp arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavities. 

It is usually single and unilateral which is more commonly seen in children and young adults. It has 3 parts namely:

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice. It is soft and can be moved up and down with a probe.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Other options:

Option A: Angiofibroma leads to severe and recurrent epistaxis and bleeds easily on probing. 

Option B: Hypertrophied turbinate feels firm on probe testing and cannot be moved up and down on probing.

Option C: Ethmoidal polyps are usually bilateral. They occur in adults.

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS
