  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with facial asymmetry. On examination, there is loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, absent acoustic reflex, and normal Schirmer test. What is the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The site of lesion in this patient with loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue and absent acoustic reflex is at the tympanic segment.

Injury to the greater superficial petrosal nerve leads to loss of lacrimation which is detected by the Schirmer test. It is the first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion.

Injury to the nerve to stapedius, the first motor branch of the facial nerve, leads to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis, which can be detected by tympanometry.

Injury to chorda tympani nerve leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected by salivary flow test.

So in this patient, the lesion is proximal to the origin of nerve to stapedius i.e. tympanic segment, and not proximal to geniculate ganglion as the lacrimation is normal.

questions.text: Currently the most common indication for the placement of the device shown in image is:

choices.text: Foreign Body Obstruction of upper airway

questions.solution:
The image shows a cuffed tracheostomy tube.

In modern times, the most common indication for tracheostomy is need for prolonged ventilatory support.

The cuffed tracheostomy tube permits positive pressure ventilation to be administered. Laryngomalacia often takes a benign course and spontaneously resolves. Certainly not a common indication for tracheostomy.

Foreign body obstruction of upper airway and subglottic hemangiomas less frequently require tracheostomy with advent of other treatment modalities.

questions.text: A known patient of Meniere’s disease experienced a sudden drop attack without loss of consciousness. There is no vertigo or fluctuations in the hearing loss. What is the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis.

It occurs in patients with Meniere’s disease where the patient develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. It is due to the change in the endolymphatic pressure leading to the deformation of the otolithic membrane of the utricle or saccule.

Tullio phenomenon - It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Lermoyez syndrome - Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

Vestibular Hydrops - The patient gets typical attacks of episodic vertigo while cochlear functions remain normal.

questions.text: An ENT resident uses the following instrument to examine the patient in OPD. The resident could see all of the following structures except _______
questions.solution:
The image shows posterior rhinoscopy mirror. Posterior ends of nasal turbinates are seen with this instrument (not the anterior ends).

St. Clair Thompson mirror is the other name for Posterior rhinoscopy Mirror. It has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

  • Adenoids
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates
  • Opening of the eustachian tube
  • The posterior border of the nasal septum
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller
  • Torus tubarius
  • The upper surface of the soft palate

Note : Laryngeal Mirror is straight without any bends with a mirror at end.
